Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2010 06:42AM Susie123 wrote: ((( HUGS ))) I am so sorry for your loss.
Posts.Title: I Mourn but yet I'm Grateful Frankie_ Frankie_

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 10:32AM Susie123 wrote: I think you need to make the decision that you are most comfortable with. Nobody knows us better than we know ourselves. I've had a life full of mamo call backs and additional testing. After knowing that I have Invasive Cancer, I felt it better to have a bmx. You see I'm a worrier. The fear and anxiety would have eaten me up inside if I had not opted for the bmx. Our life experiences also make us who we are, and I've known alot of women who started with lumpectomies and ended up with mastectomies. I just wanted the surgical part of it over. I have not regretted my decision. We can look at facts and figures all day, but in the end we have to make the personal decision for ourselves that will let us sleep at night. For some, it's keeping their breasts, for me it's getting the cancer out the most aggressive way. My best to you in whatever you decide. Susie
Posts.Title: Conflicted--L vs M? Hardest decision ever! Jdx0424 Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2013 07:19AM Susie123 wrote: drewmom, I had my first lump removed the summer I graduated from high school. Another one just a year or two later, followed by a lifetime of mamo call backs, ultrasounds, and all you described above. After all those years, 30 of them, diagnosed at age 49 with bc, none of those worrisome lumps turned into cancer. My cancer was cluster microcalcifications, like grains of salt, not even a lump. They were so small the radiologist didn't even see them, the software on the digital mamo machine flagged it. I too had no family history of bc, only fibrocystic breasts, for 30 years. All the call backs are a pain, and scary, but those follow ups found bc in its very early stage, that was unrelated to the fibrocystic issue, but found early because of the fibrocystic follow ups. Mastectomys are tough and they change you forever. I'm glad you are taking the summer to think about it.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2010 06:28AM Susie123 wrote: Sassa, Please don't be mean. Sometimes I think we can forget the reason that we all came to this board. It is for support and help through an awful time in our life. We don't all make the same decisions in life, but we all are affected by breast cancer. Our job is to support and not judge. The ladies here have helped me so much through my journey, and I still remember the panic that I felt at first. That panic is evident in this mans post. I don't want to offend you, you're a sister through this journey, but that mans wife is a sister too..on a journey that none of us want to be on. We have to support each other. ((( HUGS ))) Susie

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2010 12:00AM Susie123 wrote: I've had a blue weekend too. I've actually cried some, for seemingly no reason and that's just not normal for me. I don't know if it's lack of hormones or one of those dark times when possible recurrence is on my mind. I had my first routine (3 month) onco appointment Thursday and he said my tumor markers are about as low as he has ever seen. But then he went on to tell me my liver enzymes are high. I don't drink at all, so naturally my mind goes to mets. I go back in a month to have the liver enzymes checked again. Wouldn't it be great if we could just put all this behind us and move on to a normal life. You think you're feeling really good, and then out of nowhere, you're sitting here crying. I'm just grateful that the feeling really good times are actually most of the time. I hope yours are too.. Susie

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 01:23PM Susie123 wrote: Jeb, Right now is a really hard time, you've just been diagnosed, during the holidays when we see so many people who have so many questions and comments, some helpful and some intended to be helpful but are a source of more anxiety. I was diagnosed 3 years ago on December 22nd. My suggestion is to just go with how you feel at the time. I took Ativan as needed to deal with what I was going through and it was a blessing to have that option.Some good days, some bad days. On the bad days the Ativan helped. Please know that it will get better and easier as time passes. I remember being consumed with the thoughts that it would be my last Christmas with my kids...it wasn't, we're here now at our third and things are going well.I've met so many ladies who had breast cancer 10, 15, or 20 years ago and are still going strong.
Posts.Title: To tranquilise or not to tranquilise jebdra Momine

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2012 05:56AM Susie123 wrote: Kaara, my liver enzymes have been elevated too. I had a liver ct, it was good. I had a nuclear bone scan, it was good. The onco said he sees a few people each week that have no issues other than elevated liver enzymes that he doesn't understand why. I don't drink either, never have, and other than BC, I've had no other health issues. He wanted to cover all bases so he sent me to a liver Dr and a bone Dr. When they did more detailed blood work, one for liver, one for bone, individually they came back normal even though the liver enzymes at the onco still are elevated at every appointment.
Posts.Title: Elevated liver enzymes Kaara beacon800

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2010 05:09PM Susie123 wrote: Hi Dana, All of the above meds make me itch all over and knock me out. I just ask my Dr today for a script for tramadol. I work at a pharmacy and ask my Rph what would be a good non narcotic pain reliever and she suggested tramadol. She said they dispense alot of it. I got the script today, but havn't taken any yet. You might want to check with your Dr or Rph to see if this would be an option for you. It really stinks to be in pain. I hope this helps, Susie
Posts.Title: Allergic reaction to pain medicine and antibiotics dana14 Susie123

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2010 04:40PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:00AM by Susie123 Lisa, Otter said it well. That's pretty much what my onco said too. Your diagnosis line is pretty much the same as mine. The only thing that changed after my mastectomy was the size of the tumor, which was bigger than they thought initially, but still a stage 1. For an invasive breast cancer, you have the best kind to possibly have. I know that sounds strange, but as you find out more about breast cancer you will realize how important that is. It's the least aggressive (grade 1), hormone positive (because they have meds to treat that well) and you're her 2 negative, which is very good. It's perfectly normal to be extremely worried and freak out a little at any ache or pain that's not normal. It will get easier as time passes, I promise. If the anxiety gets to be to much, ask your Dr for an anxiety med, it's perfectly normal to be overwhelmed when you've just been told you have cancer. Something you never thought you would ever hear, and still can't quite believe it. (((( HUGS )))) Susie

I truly believe most mastectomies are on women who don't have a choice due to more advanced cancer, thus the results of that particular study...not the results for those of us who had a choice.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 07:30PM Susie123 wrote: I'm so sorry you're dealing with this. The cancer treatment alone is a huge decision, but couple that with fertility issues and it becomes almost an impossible decision. I didn't have kids until mid life, not by choice, I just couldn't get pregnant. We had been married for 13 years when I gave birth to our oldest son, after going through the fertility tests and treatments. I know how hard it is, wanting kids, but not being able to have them. I honestly don't know how I would handle that if it had overlapped my BC. You have a really hard decision that only you and your husband can make. Please know that you will be in my thoughts and prayers. I'm so sorry. This is one of those moments in life that just stinks. ((( HUGS ))) Susie
Posts.Title: Chemo or No Chemo Truly Cant Decide jhalvors cookiegal

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 10:20AM Susie123 wrote: Bring a button down top to wear home since you won't be able to raise your arms to put on a pullover for a while. Bring a small pillow to go between your chest and the seatbelt for the ride home. For the first few days, be sure to take your pain meds as prescribed, don't wait for it to start hurting to take one. This will keep unnecessary pain away. If possible, have someone stay with you for he first week after coming home to take care of the normal day to day household duties and the kids, if you have any. Just go in with the mindset that you will get through this and then power right through it. You are stronger than you think. ((Hugs))
Posts.Title: Mastectomy with reconstruction coming up....VERY NERVOUS 1MindyydniM1 Skiergirl

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 06:59PM Susie123 wrote: Hi, I pretty much stayed in the lovely hospital gown the entire time. You do need a housecoat and slippers for walking in the hall. You need a pillow for the seat belt and a button down top for the trip home, you can't lift your arms well enough for a pullover. Pretty much anything beyond that I didn't use. As far as visitors, I had them, but was very much not myself on pain meds. I have a very low tolerance for meds so the pain meds really did a number on me. It seems that I showed my niece that it didn't really look that bad by just raising my gown all the way up. The problem was, her husband was standing right beside her. I would have NEVER done that if I were in my right mind. Of course that was immediately following surgery when they first brought me to my room. I don't think I flashed anyone else, hopefully not, since my pastor also visited.
Posts.Title: While in the Hospital photobug Diane509

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 06:20PM Susie123 wrote: Kody, I'm so sorry. This is really hard especially at first. After you see the breast surgeon you will have more answers, but most of the info is not available until after the surgery when the main pathology report comes in. Don't be so worried about them taking lymph nodes. They don't just take them randomly anymore. It's more of a science and they take as few as possible. It's common practice to check the lymph nodes now so please don't think that means your cancer is worse than your moms was. If you need anxiety meds to help you get through, please do call your Dr. And it sounds like things turned out well for your mom, it's been 17 years. That's awesome. Hang in there, things will get easier when you have a game plan. This is probably the hardest part, when your diagnosed but have little information. With each Dr visit, test, or procedure those puzzle pieces will start clicking together and your plan to kick cancers but will become clearer. (( Hugs )) Susie

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 09:55AM Susie123 wrote: Hi Lindy, I see that you're grade 3, that is an aggressive cancer that would respond to chemo. I was diagnosed with stage 1 grade 1 six months ago. I had a oncotype score of 16 and the onco said no chemo. At my very first three month onco visit a liver enzyme was elevated. He thought it was because I had just had exchange surgery and they would come down. We waited a month and retested, they didn't come down. We waited another month and retested, yesterday. I'm waiting on the results. If it hasn't came down this time, I will need a liver and bone scan to check for mets. I just can't wrap my mind around the possibility that I have gone from stage 1 to stage 4 in 6 months. I also am very worried that I didn't have chemo. It's a hard decision that we all have to make and never know if we've made the right one. It looks like you're still very young, and with the grade 3 cancer chemo would be effective because grade 3 cancer cells grow much faster than normal cells.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2010 08:49PM Susie123 wrote: I had a bilateral eight weeks ago even though my left breast was clear. For me, it was the right decision. I have two friends who chose to only have one removed, and now face constant worry due to testing and repeated biopsies on the one they have left. I'm a worrier, so that's not for me. I didn't want to face the possibility of having to go through this again in a few years. I also had reconstruction (tissue expanders)  at the same time. The expansion process has been more painful than I expected, but I'm glad I did that as well. I wish you the best in whatever you decide is right for you! Susie

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2014 01:21PM Susie123 wrote: I'm so sorry about the loss of your husband and the extreme sadness that brings. It sounds like you've been through so much lately. You should not feel ashamed because the Dr was so mad sounding, the Dr should be ashamed for acting that way. Have the mammogram to get it checked out and then find another Dr. I have breast cancer and I had no symptoms at all. Also try and find comfort in the knowledge that most lumps are not cancer. You sound totally overwhelmed, is there anybody you can see locally for support? Maybe a counselor, support group, or a therapist? Sometimes life puts so much on our plate that it's hard to handle alone. We're here to help too. Start by getting that mamo and staying off google. When we google things to much we see ALL the what ifs, when it's unlikely any of it will relate to us as individuals. Also know that you're not alone, there are a lot of very compassionate ladies here that are willing to help. ((Hugs))   Susie

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 11:49AM Susie123 wrote: I think at the beginning I did obsess about the how me, why me aspect of BC, but as time passes that feeling goes away a bit, being replaced with the is this really how I want to live my life question. I had an awful job that was very stressful working for a horrible company, that I just kept mindlessly doing year after year because of the higher pay. BC made me realize that life's to short and I quit that job. I've learned to live on less and what is truly important in life isn't bought with money. I don't think we will ever know why we got it or how it can be prevented. We just learn to appreciate each day more. :)
Posts.Title: What changes have you made after dx? Speedy4 msphil

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 04:09PM Susie123 wrote: I just had my exchange surgery 2 days ago. I also had one of the tissue expanders that had turned sideways, was much lower than the other one, and was trying to run under my arm. My PS said not to worry, she would do a little pocket work and they would be even after the exchange surgery. I came home in this really tight surgical bra, but the best I can tell they're pretty even now. I just have more of a valley in the middle than I would like, but from what I hear it takes a few weeks, or months for them to fluff and look their best. They are so much softer and even with the tight surgical bra on, it feels so much better than the TE did. No more iron bra 24/7.
Posts.Title: These %$@* TEs! joyko mawhinney

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 02:18PM Susie123 wrote: The grade of the cancer also has an effect on it. Grade 1 is less aggressive and usually doesn't respond well to chemo. Grade 3 is more aggressive and does respond well to chemo, the cancer cells grow much faster than normal cells so chemo is usually the ticket for a grade 3. Hormonal treatment for ER+ stage 1 grade 1 is the norm there. Her 2 positive usually gets you chemo and hercepton as well. That's some commonalities that I've noticed.
Posts.Title: Factors lowering oncotype lola12 lago

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2012 10:18PM Susie123 wrote: Jojo, I too live in a very small town. I did not have my surgery at the small local hospital. I went to a group of surgeons who only do breast cancer surgeries in the city (Atlanta) even though it was a few hours from home. I felt more comfortable having a surgeon who only dealt with breast cancer day in & day out instead of just a general surgeon. As far as timeline, after diagnosis it was almost a month before the surgery. I too am a worrier and chose the bmx. Another good thing with a bigger hospital is that the breast surgeon coordinates with the plastic surgeon who starts the reconstruction process during the same surgery as well as the sentinel node biopsy at the same time which saves having more lymph nodes removed than necessary which is important. As far as the timeline, it was over a week before the breast surgeon and the plastic surgeon could coordinate their schedules and an OR was available so if Hawaii is immediately after the breast surgeon it probably would be at least that long a wait anyway. It's a very personal decision on the small town hospital with general surgeon or the big city specialist and hospital. I have friends who chose the small town, but I know that I wouldn't have been happy with that, but I also understand wanting it out now! I felt the same and in my case the local surgeon and hospital would have been quicker, but in my opinion not better. My best to you in whatever you choose.
Posts.Title: Now what?? jojo69 Linda-Ranching-in-the-mTns

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2010 04:50PM - edited Mar 21, 2010 04:52PM by Susie123 I am so sorry that you have to go through this. I have two teenage sons and had a bilateral mast with tissue expanders on Jan 21st. You're going through the worst time right now. I cried for 3 days when I was diagnosed, then I was mad, sad, and then just numb. I know it doesn 't seem like it now, but it will get easier. Be sure to take something that buttons down the front, not pullover, to wear home from the hospital. You won't be able to lift your arms well. Take a pillow to put under the seat belt for the ride home. Plan on having extra help with your son for a week or two. Pain meds will be your friend for a while, but each day you will feel a little better than the day before. You'll be amazed at how strong you are. We're all stronger than we know. A friend gave me a shirt with the pink ribbon and the words "fight like a girl", I know it's kinda corny, but that became my mindset. I wore that shirt to the hospital on surgery day. So you go in the morning and fight like a girl!  If I can help in any way please feel free to PM me. I check this board almost every day.  Sending you ((( HUGS ))) and keeping you in my prayers, Susie

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2010 12:48AM Susie123 wrote: One of the little girls at our church, who is only in middle school, recently realized that cancer is all around her.  I sit on the pew in front of her and was diagnosed with bc at Christmas time, the man who sits on the pew in front of me was diagnosed with prostate cancer within about a month. Then a couple of months later a boy at her school was diagnosed with leukemia, and a month later a girl there was also diagnosed with cancer. This girls mother said the little girl is consumed with worry that she is going to get it too...it's so sad, less than a year ago this kid didn't even realize that cancer existed.

They take you behind a GLASS wall, so everybody sees you. I told them about the BC, BMX, and reconstruction with implants. It was originally a male TSA agent, he called for a female who actually patted my breasts down. They both were very nice and looked more uncomfortable about the situation than I was. The female touched my foobs very lightly with the back of her hands. It is a little strange, but I understand why they have to do it. I'm just glad that's not my job:)

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 11:10PM Susie123 wrote: Hi Glenda, I wish you the best with your decision. I know two ladies who live in my community who went the lumpectomy route, about 5 years apart, with different surgeons, who had the same first experience that you did. The margins were not clear. They chose an additional lumpectomy. The pathology came back on the second surgery just as it did on the first lumpectomy, margins were not clear. They ended up with a mastectomy. That was three surgeries to endure. They both wish they would have just had the mastectomy to begin with, and both shared their feelings with me when I was diagnosed and trying to make the lumpectomy/mastectomy decision. It's a very personal choice for all of us, but I wanted to share this with you, as they did with me. ((( HUGS ))) Susie
Posts.Title: STANFORD U RECOMMENDS THREE LUMPECTOMIES B4 MASTECTOMY Glendora celia088

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 05:52PM Susie123 wrote: ohh luckystar, I was where you are now three years ago. My diagnosis and oncotype score is very similar to yours, which Beesie is right, odds are we won't die from breast cancer. I remember my greatest fear was leaving my kids. The first year was awful, I just couldn't shake that horrible feeling that you have now. But, after we got through that first year with every milestone, holidays, birthdays, school activities, all thinking it would be my last with my kids, I started to feel better about having a future. My fear, over time, subsided and yours will too even though it doesn't feel like it now. As far as an invasive breast cancer diagnosis go, ours is very early stage. No one can tell us with certainty if it will recur, but odds are absolutely on our side. After the initial fear, I've taken it as a wake up call to live my life the way I want to. I have a little saying on my desk, don't count the days, make the days count. It helps remember to live, not just get by. We're also about the same age, I'll be 53 in a few months. Hang in there, let yourself feel all the emotions, but please take solace in the fact it will get easier as time passes.
Posts.Title: Will I Die? luckystar netty46

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 07:26AM - edited May 7, 2010 07:27AM by Susie123 I had cluster microcalcifications too, DCIS and IDC. I had a bmx in Jan with tissue expanders placed to begin the reconstruction. They will do a MRI before surgery so they can better see what they're dealing with. An MRI shows much better detail than the mamo. They also take the first look at the lymph nodes with the MRI. Hang in there, I know it feels like it's taking forever to get to surgery and you just want it out of you. Before I had BC I didn't realize that the cancer has been in us for years, so a week or two wait won't make a big difference. Grade 2 is in the middle so it's not the extremely aggressive grade 3. Now is a really hard time. It will get better. Hang in there. I was told that microcalcifications mean it has been caught early too, and found that to be true. ((( HUGS ))) Susie

Posts.Title: How many years have you been a Survivor? IllinoisNancy Lou789

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2010 06:25PM Susie123 wrote: Tammy, My breast cancer was found by a mamo as "cluster calcification's". I was told that many women over 40 have calcification's and usually they are not cancer as long as they are scattered. When they can indicate cancer, they're very small, like grains of salt, and grouped together in tight clusters.  Susie
Posts.Title: Calcifications in "other breast" " eight months after chemo comingtoterms Titan

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2010 11:36AM Susie123 wrote: Hi jo123, Let me start by saying that calcifications do not always mean cancer. It's normal for us to have some calcifications as we age. The problem occurs when they become "cluster calcifications", which can be the earliest stages of breast cancer. My "cluster calcifications" did turn out to be early breast cancer, but I had no pain in my breast at all. I understand your level of anxiety. My diagnosis is still fairly fresh. I was told that it was BC 3 days before Christmas. At the time I thought it was the worst thing that could ever happen, especially at Christmas time. Since then I have came to see it as being a blessing. I know that sounds odd, but catching it this early makes so much difference in being able to survive BC. I know it's really hard not to worry, but the breast surgeon told me that 85% of the time calcifications turn out to be nothing. Please try to take comfort in the fact that even if you're in the 15% that is BC, it's very early stage and has a very good prognosis. I didn't need chemo and was given only a 5% chance of recurrence in the next 10 years. For that I am very grateful for the early detection. Hang in there... ((( HUGS  ))) Susie
Posts.Title: Worried calcifications jo123 Lisa1962

Posts.Title: Doing Sentinel Node Biopsy when you are under anesthesia Cowgirl13 NSWTD

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 06:07AM Susie123 wrote: Hi Nancy, I'm stage 1 grade 1, with no ovaries and do take Arimidex every day. Even without ovaries you still have estrogen stored in your tissues, and you adrenal gland produces it. If you are ER+ then you need to take the hormone therapy. It gives us a better chance of beating this for good. ER+ cancers feed on estrogen, that's how they grow. We have to cut off that food supply. The hormone therapy does just that. I would definately do the Arimidex. Susie

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 10:56PM Susie123 wrote: I was diagnosed three days before Christmas and my bmx was during the third week of Jan. Between the biopsy results and surgery I had a MRI and appointment with the plastic surgeon concerning reconstruction. The surgery was then scheduled based on when the breast surgeon and plastic surgeon had openings in their OR schedules at the same time. It's normal to want it out NOW when we hear the cancer word. My breast surgeon assured me that it was not going to make a difference to wait a few weeks. You should know more about what you're dealing with after your appointment. Just try to hang in there. ((Hugs))

Ouch! Back to the pain pills for a couple of days. All in all, I feel very blessed to have had this outcome, I know my fellow early stagers feel the same. Great to find this thread. By the way, my name is Susie, and I live in the North Georgia Mountains. Nice to talk with ya'll !

Posts.Title: Remission or "cured"? Halah wobbly

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 12:04PM - edited Apr 28, 2010 02:09PM by Susie123 Hi Polyana, Find a good breast surgeon, I live in a rural area and had to drive 2 hours to Atlanta to get a Breast Surgeon. They only do breast cancer patients, unlike general surgeons who do everything. It looks like you have DCIS as well as IDC, which is the same thing I had. It also looks like your cancer cells are well differentiated, which was also the same as mine. If you have to get an invasive cancer, then that is what you want. It means the cancer cells still look very similar to your regular cells, so it's a low grade cancer. Your treatment options will be determined by the size of the cancer and it's location within the breast. Stats for survival are determined by the final pathology report after your surgery. So far you sound alot like mine, I ended up with no chemo, just a pill called Arimidex for 5 years, and a survival rate of 95% . Hang in there and try not to drive yourself crazy worrying. I know it's hard and feels like it's taking forever, but what they don't do is a very good job of explaining to you how it's a step by step process. The results of one test will determine what the next step is. You will also need an oncologist. Make sure that the oncologist follows NCCN protocol. That means they're treating based on the latest research and protocol. Sending you warm hugs, this is really a hard time, but it will get better. Susie

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 10:53AM Susie123 wrote: Hi Holly, I've had elevated ALP for months now. I've had the liver CT, it was normal. I've also had the nuclear bone scan, it was normal. My onco then sent me to a gastro, he did tests, they were normal. I've had all the tests and they still don't know why! The onco said he see's that in several of his patients, but doesn't know why, and it doesn't cause any other problems. Mine are around 178 and the gastro said that isn't high enough to damage the liver. I just had bloodwork for my 3 month checkup today. I'll find out next week if they're up again. I've noticed that if I gain weight, they go up. When I was on a diet and watching what I ate, they actually went down. Susie

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 08:09AM Susie123 wrote: Call backs arn't necessarily a bad thing. I had very dense fibrocystic breasts and had multiple callbacks for 30 years that were all fine. They were all to get a better view of the fibrocystic lumps that had been there my whole life. My first one was removed when I was 17 and it's been monitored since then. I was 49 when I got BC, and after all those years of mamo call backs to get better views of the lumps, it wasn't any of the lumps that were BC. I had cluster microcalcifications on the last mamo that was BC. Try not to worry to much. I had 30 years of callbacks that were nothing. Susie

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 05:09PM Susie123 wrote: Mine was a small cluster of micro calcification's. The Dr at Breast Care Specialists told me there was an 85% chance it was benign. I had a stereotactic biopsy that was ultrasound guided. From what the Dr said, they're so tiny, it's like a bunch of grains of salt. The micro calcification's themselves are normal as we age. They become concerning when they're bunched in tight clusters. On the positive side, if it does turn out to be cancer, it's very early stage with a very high cure rate.

My oncotype came back with no surprises, everything was the same as my pathology reports but it did save me from chemo. Since I have IDC, in the old days that would have bought me chemo without a doubt. With the oncotype test results my oncologist said no chemo. He said there would only be a 1% to 2% net benefit from the chemo after removing the 3% risk of chemo. I'm very grateful for the oncotype dx test.
Posts.Title: I think Oncotype DX is a SCAM!! peppopat mysticalcity

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 08:32AM Susie123 wrote: Yes, you will smile again and hopefully by Christmas this will be just a memory. I was diagnosed 3 days before Christmas, BMX with TE reconstruction in Jan, exchange surgery in April. I thought my world had ended just 6 months ago. I always shop after Christmas sales to begin my Christmas shopping for the next year but I didn't do that, I thought my life was over. It wasn't. By spring I was back to normal. Planning for the future, feeling like I actually have a future again. You do have some tough time ahead of you, getting through the mastectomy and the reconstruction, but honestly it wasn't nearly as bad as I thought it would be. As far as if you want the reconstruction, ask your BS to see pictures of what it looks like without it. Then look at some pictures with it. That will help you decide. Talk with a PS before your mastectomy too so if you do decide on the reconstruction they can do it in the same surgery. About what  questions to ask, I recommend going to the Susan G Komen website. They have printable lists of questions to ask the Drs at every stage of the journey and they're very good. Be sure to write down the answers as the Dr gives them to you. You think you're listening and comprehending what they're saying, but you won't remember everything, it's just to overwhelming. As far as a support group, I live in a small town, we don't have one. The ladies here have become my support group. As you go through all this keep focused on the good in your diagnosis, BC is never a good thing, but with DCIS your cancer is contained. It hasn't became invasive, your prognosis is awesome. Hang in there, it does get easier.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 07:00PM Susie123 wrote: There's another one at "cancer math". It doesn't lump everyone together. You enter the exacts on size, grade, er, pr, her 2, etc..Just google cancer math and the link will come up. Someone posted a link to it on another thread here and I found it to be very helpful. What I saw there was more in line with what the onco said...but who knows. I think in the end, it's a crap shoot. Having a low % chance of recurrence is great, as long as you're not in the small % that does recur. When I had my biopsy, the Dr told me to go home, don't worry, there's an 85% chance it's nothing and she really felt it was ok...needless to say it wasn't ok. Once you've been on the wrong side of the statistics, they're not as comforting anymore.

Posts.Title: How to pick a medical oncologist? dense Miles2Go

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 04:57PM Susie123 wrote: Hi, As someone in her early 50's who had her first lump surgically removed at the age of 17, I can tell you that back then it was normal to have surgery with anesthesia to have a lump removed and checked to see if it was cancer. I had another one at 19, surgery with anesthesia, to find again it was benign. By the time I had my third surgery in my 20's, the normal procedure was to have it removed with a "local" in the hospital instead of having anesthesia. As time progressed, the final biopsy at age 49, which showed IDC was a stereotactic. I took it as the progression of medicine, learning newer and less invasive methods to achieve the same results. But I do understand your concern. I too was worried that the last biopsy had spread the cancer, but I would have had the same worry about spreading the cancer if it had been diagnosed in 1977 with the first surgical biopsy where the lump was removed "in tact" as well. I think that comes from having heard so many times through my life others comments about cancer patients, " you know they were doing so well until that Dr did _ _ and the it just spread all over. I think the truth is, we never really know how we got it, just as we never know how or if it will spread. I do think the stereotactic biopsy is the best available now. Even with my fear, I don't regret having it. I hope you will find peace with it too.
Posts.Title: Do FNA and Stereotactic Core Needle Biopsy cause "seeding"of BC? learningtoletgo letsgogolf

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 07:44AM Susie123 wrote: I think we all mourn a little for what was. I had a bmx in Jan, te's exchanged for the implants in April, no chemo, no rads, just arimidex. Easy compared to some. I still don't feel normal. I'm tired alot, fall a sleep sitting in the chair at night sometimes. That's not me, old people do that!...but now that is me, it's hard to accept the changes as we try to adjust to our new lives. Will the hormonals we're taking leave us this way the whole 5 years? We don't know. I feel like I've aged 10 years in the past 10 months. It is depressing. But then I remember that at least I am aging, still able to see my children grow up ( teenage years, so that's a challenge in itself ), doing college visitations with my 17 year old, taking trips to see things I've always wanted to see but always put off in the past, living...Then I try to see beyond that old fat lady that can't stay awake past 8pm and whose knees have difficulty bending now ..It's hard, and sometimes I do get in a sad place, it's hard not to...but cancer has already taken so much from us, we can't let it take what's left.

Posts.Title: stage 1 what test do you have sheri47 kira1234

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2010 09:09AM Susie123 wrote: I know it's frustrating but they don't do the staging until after the surgery. The biopsy and initial testing can give some insight, but they won't know for sure until after the surgery. Some folks have chemo before because the tumor is so large, they try to shrink it before hand. Your tumor is not that big so you would not have chemo before. Depending on your final path report (after surgery) you may not need chemo at all. Your initial findings show a tumor the size of a stage 1 tumor. As long as there is no lymph node or vascular involvement, and you end up hormone positive and her2 negative (that kind of info will be on your final path report after surgery) you may not need chemo at all. So much of the treatment can't be determined until that final path report is in. I know it's really hard to wait, each day seems like a lifetime, but it will get easier after the surgery is done and you have that path report. You will have a plan of action then, and feel a little more in control of the cancer instead it totally controlling your every thought right now. Hang in there and take it one day at a time. I promise, it does get easier. Susie

Posts.Title: This made me angry... Am I over-reacting? Anne068 kelben

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 04:45PM Susie123 wrote: Hi, I too had a low oncotype score and didn't have chemo. One of the best ways to understand it is to understand how chemo works. My cancer was grade 1, which means the cancer cells are very similar to normal cells. In grade 1 cancers the "bad cells" don't grow much faster than the "good cells". Chemo destroys ALL cells, both cancerous and good ones,equally, it can't differentiate between a cancer cell and a normal cell. For chemo to be very effective you must have the higher grade cancer where the cells are very different from normal ones and multiply and grow at a much faster rate than your normal cells do. That way it kills the faster growing and multiplying cancer cells before it kills you. With the lower grade, both good and bad cells grow and multiply at about the same rate. Chemo wouldn't help us just because of the nature of our cancer. And it's good that our cancer is low grade. Stage 1, Grade 1 is the best you can have for an invasive cancer. Of course that's not an absolute guarantee that it will never come back. We all have to make decisions that we feel are best for us, but never truely know if we've made the right one.  Do your research, and then go with what you feel is right for you, then put it in Gods hands. It will drive you crazy if you worry about "if" you made the right choice. I wish you the best with your decision. Susie
Posts.Title: Meaning of low Oncotype Dx score sling99 cuddyclothes

Posts.Content: Susie123 wrote: Has anyone felt this way other than me? I'm 8 weeks post bilateral mast and have returned to work a couple of weeks ago. The last several years my job has became more and more stressful and it seems like none of us can satisfy corporate. I'm so tired of it and now that I've had cancer I'm starting to wonder if it's worth it. I could live to be 90, or BC could come back next month. We don't know how long we have to live and I would hate to think that I lived my last year on this earth so miserable. But then I think I must be crazy to even consider leaving a job when so many can't find work, and my insurance there is wonderful. I also have teenage children and my job supplies them with so many extras they wouldn't have if I quit. How do we decide what is more important? Dx 12/22/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/8 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2013 01:31PM Susie123 wrote: I went through all the fertility tests / treatments in 1991/1992. Finally conceived with the help of clomid and gave birth to a healthy baby boy in 1993. My Dr told me that with a hormonal problem such as mine, wasn't ovulating, it tends to correct itself after giving birth so we might want to be careful if we didn't want a second child. Of course we ignored the Drs advice, I'd been barren for 13 years. Turns out, he was right. Had another son the very next year with no fertility drugs. But, you know, even if clomid did give me bc I wouldn't change a thing. Those boys have been the light of my life. The oldest just went back to college yesterday and I'm so sad. I've came to the realization that God doesn't give us our kids, he only loans them to us for a short period of time...that short period that seems like your forever life. :(

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 07:31AM Susie123 wrote: Hi Raili, I can understand your issues with percentages not being comforting anymore. With my biopsy the Dr was very positive. She assured me there was an 85% chance it was nothing, that worse case we were dealing with a little DCIS. Then three days before Christmas she called to tell me it was Invasive Cancer. After that, I've had to really work on overcoming the percentage thing in my mind. I think the SNB is the least invasive type they can do. I had it, no problems. I have a friend who had the node biopsy the old school way 4 years ago and she still has to wear a compression sleeve for lymphedema. I know we've both been "burned" by the percentage thing, but we can't let that drive our future decisions. It's probably easier for me to say that because I'm a few months out now. It's still fresh for you, and it's alot harder then. It'll get easier. Sending you ((((((((((((((((((((( H U G S )))))))))))))))))))) Susie
